title: Maesglase
text:
Maesglase is a <a href="mountain">mountain</a> in <a href="Snowdonia">Snowdonia</a>, <a href="North%20Wales">North Wales</a>, situated approximately four miles to the south-west of <a href="Aran%20Fawddwy">Aran Fawddwy</a>. It is the highest of the <a href="Dyfi%20Hills">Dyfi Hills</a>.
It can be reached by an easy but steep walk through the forestry from <a href="Dinas%20Mawddwy">Dinas Mawddwy</a> or directly from the <a href="Mountain%20pass">bwlch</a> on the <a href="A470%20road">A470</a>. Ascending Maesglase provides an opportunity to climb several other nearby peaks including Maen-Du, Craig Rhiw-erch, <a href="Waun-oer">Waun-oer</a>, Craig Portas and <a href="Cribin%20Fawr">Cribin Fawr</a> which are linked by a series of ridges and <a href="ar%C3%AAte">arête</a>s.
The precise location of the summit is the subject of some confusion. Traditionally, the top of Maen Du ( at ) was regarded as Maesglase's summit. However, more recent surveys suggest that the top of Craig Rhiw-erch ("c" at , some to the west) is higher. A recent survey puts it at . The <a href="geomorphology">geomorphology</a> of these mountains is classical U-shaped <a href="glacial%20valley">glacial valley</a>s with textbook examples of <a href="hanging%20valley">hanging valley</a>s and intersecting valleys.
The eastern slopes are devoted to sheep farming whilst the western slopes are intensively forested.
Above the semi-improved <a href="grassland">grassland</a> is some <a href="bracken">bracken</a> but much of the higher ground is covered in typical "<a href="Calluna">Calluna</a>" / "<a href="Erica%20%28plant%29">Erica</a>" communities interspersed with large areas of "<a href="Juncus">Juncus</a>", "<a href="Carex">Carex</a>" and "<a href="Sphagnum">Sphagnum</a>" bogs. The tops of Cribin Fawr are flat expanses of peat-hags. On the eastern flanks <a href="Bilberry">Bilberry</a> ("Vaccinium myrtillus") grows in abundance with <a href="Vaccinium%20vitis-idaea">Cowberry</a> ("Vaccinium vitis-idaea") common on the highest ground.
Half a mile to the west of the peak of Cribin Fawr at a high point of is a stone <a href="boundary%20marker">boundary marker</a> dated 1861 and inscribed CCC and bearing a <a href="Benchmark%20%28surveying%29">benchmark</a>. Maesglase waterfall has a total height of .
To the south lie the parallel ridges leading to <a href="Mynydd%20Dolgoed">Mynydd Dolgoed</a> and <a href="Mynydd%20Gartheiniog">Mynydd Gartheiniog</a>.
